X[S] \
The SyncTool\ \
Welcome to the SyncTool, the tool that complements the new method for syncing [\TWiki page\] of \stuff\ between the various servers in the Skotosphere. \ \{? \| \$(UDat.dat.sync:seen-verbose) \| \ \ \\$[\$udat."sync:seen-verbose" = nil;]\ \ \ \ \ \| \\$[\$udat."sync:seen-verbose" = TRUE;]\ \
\\This message will only appear once.\\ \
Until now, there has been one master and one slave; the master has been a dictator and the slaves have been forced to accept all submissions from the master. Furthermore, slaves could not easily suggest or propose changes to be included in the Skotosphere, which has, to put it bluntly, been a road block to the various games' ability to cooperate. \ \
The basic idea behind this tool is as follows: \ \
if you change an object that is in the \shared Skotosphere\ (currently the Shared: folder only), your modifications will be noticed and you can decide one of 3 things to do with your modified version\ \
if you create a \new\ object and put it in the shared Skotosphere, you can then decide what to do with your new object\ \ Once you have an object that is new, or contains changes that you think should be added to the world, you can use \this tool\ to tell the system to \propose\ your changes. If you'd rather keep your object local, you can do that too. If you do, the Skotosphere version will no longer be synced to your game. The three available options are these: \ \
\discard\ -- discarding an object means you want to start using the Skotosphere version again\ \
\ignore\ -- ignoring an object means you want the object to stay as is, and to \ignore\ all updates from the master\ \
\propose\ -- proposing an object means you want the object added to, or the modifications made included in, the Skotosphere\ \ If you do propose an object, one of two things will happen: \ \
\your proposal is accepted\ -- your local copy will be discarded and replaced by the master version (because the master version \is\ your local version at that point)\ \
\your proposal is declined\ -- your local copy will switch to \ignore\ from \propose\ here; you will never lose your own changes unless you decide to lose them yourself\ \ \ \ \} \
Here below is the queue, listing items that have been modified locally: \ \$[html::table(\$alignment: "center", \$padding: 0, \$rules: "all", \$style: "border: solid #dddddd 1px;", \$content: ::forge_queue_table())]

"Kalle"
